awd_titl_txt: EXP: Collaborative Research: Smart Spaces for Making: Networked Physical Tools to Support Process Documentation and Learning
awd_abstract_narration:
This exploratory learning research and design project will study how to use emerging technologies to help document practices in maker-based learning experiences. Despite its established potential for consolidating learning and sense-making, project documentation is often overlooked, not prioritized or seen as burdensome and therefore not integrated into the learning experiences. The project team seeks to understand and address with practice partners the barriers to documentation by systematically exploring how to physically embed and incorporate smart tools and documentation practices into learning environments, specifically creative hands-on learning spaces, like makerspaces. The goal is to understand how to scaffold learners to become more aware, reflective and attentive to their progress towards learning outcomes by embedding supportive tools physically in space as the actions unfold. Making and maker-based learning experiences offer tremendous opportunities to more fully engage diverse learners in STEM education and build a workforce prepared for innovation. Documentation of these learning experiences, both as an authentic practice that professionals engage in as well as an assessment practice for instruction, is often not supported.  The project will create open source documentation for solutions and develop supporting case studies, web resources and guides to facilitate easy uptake and adoption of promising approaches.

This proposal will make significant research contributions in three ways: (1) develop and iteratively test a suite of embedded "smart" tools designed to scaffold, manage and trace process documentation practices; (2) study the integration of these tools in formal and informal activities and programs settings and characterize their influence on instruction and the assessment of learning outcomes; (3) establish a set of rubrics based on learner data streams to aid instruction and mark learner progress.  Improving documentation practices and the assessment of learning outcomes will advance making as a core STEM educational activity. Through a better understanding of why and how to place networked documentation tools sensitive to space, time and context cues, the threshold for enactment and scaffolded usage can be lowered in a broader range of settings.  Ultimately, this exploratory project will not only develop an integrated set of situated documentation tools, but also help us develop hypotheses for how documentation as a mediating process productively supports learning.

por.por_cntn:
The digital and physical artifacts of project documentation play an increasingly prominent role in learning, and the assessment of learning in creative, constructive, and project-based educational environments. Smart Making Spaces sought to characterize and study how documentation practices were both taught and enacted by learners, and then prototype hybrid systems designed to further documentation practices and the associated learning behaviors of noticing, reflection, articulation and critique, which process documentation often mediates. The work produced two design cases developed in extended co-design processes with educators in higher education, high school, and informal learning settings. 

The project team developed and studied the use of the ioRef.org system, a creativity and instructional support toolset for introductory physical computing courses. The integrated set of physical and digital support tools builds on a QR-code enabled playing card deck illustrating electronic parts and key conceptual categories (inputs, outputs, power, controllers) linked to an online knowledge guide to help bridge access to creative know-how, curated course references, snippet code and exemplars. Through deployment in five courses, we found the ioRef system to be a versatile resource for learning to recognize electronic components; enhance communication specificity regarding physical design features, support collaborative problem-solving and debugging of code and component failures, and finally aid in the transition from block to schematic diagramming in the layout interactive digital projects. We also demonstrated tool efficacy in remote instructional contexts necessitated by pandemic teaching and learning conditions. The second system fully prototyped and studied was the Self-Directed Learning (SDL) Evidence Kit — a hybrid set of documentation support tools for high school students that spans home to school setting — that aims to structure, manage and retrieve documentation for use as evidence of learning for microcredentials. The SDL curriculum offers students a flexible, individualized and interest-driven learning experience where they pursue various competency-based micro-credentials that they earn by collecting evidence of progress and learning. The take-home SDL Evidence Kit includes a take-home poster, visual progress tracker cards that link to a digital system for uploading, tagging, explaining, and curating evidence using a modified Google classroom service. Uploaded documentation is automatically filed by microcredential, viewable on interactive timelines that tracks microcredential progress and evidence type. The kit was deployed in Spring 2021 to over 60 students.

Results from this work showed students appreciated various features of the systems including recognizing, structuring, and managing documentation as evidence of learning.  Lastly, we conducted an extended documentation probe study with college students enrolled in interdisciplinary design-arts-tech focused courses to better understand the roles, purposes and values that documentation activates in a creative learning experience. Derived from student reported data over two semesters, nine categories were identified as reasons why student value documentation (reflection, communication, demonstration, self-regulation, record keeping, project management, creative process, proof, and instructor requirement). The results of this exploratory award provide worked examples of co-designed systems developed with educators to support the teaching and learning documentation practices, as well as contribute to the understudied area of learning design scholarship that describes how students configure, value and enact documentation in studio and maker type learning environments.

This research establishes documentation as a valued and increasingly sophisticated practice being taken up by an emerging class of creative technology professionals where evidence of learning, progress and skill attainment is gathered through process documentation and which becomes the basis for portfolios, which can unlock future educational and career opportunities.
